deliberation: The verse literally commands Ezekiel to take a brick and inscribe Jerusalem on it. Within the chapter this brick clearly functions as a symbolic stand‑in for the real city under judgment, so the action itself is an enacted metaphor/sign‑act, even though the wording is concrete. I treat the brick-as-city representation as one figurative instance.

deliberation: The language describes building siege works against the inscribed city on the brick. Literally Ezekiel is arranging a model siege, but this dramatized siege represents the future historical siege of Jerusalem. This is one extended enacted metaphor/sign‑act.

deliberation: This verse explicitly labels the whole set‑up as a 'sign' for Israel. deliberation: The verse describes Ezekiel lying on his left side and says he will 'bear the iniquity' of the house of Israel. The physical posture is part of a sign‑act, and the phrase 'bear iniquity' is a metaphorical/idiomatic expression drawn from the idea of carrying a burden.

deliberation: This verse quantifies the sign‑act (390 days) and reiterates that Ezekiel will 'bear the iniquity' of the house of Israel. deliberation: Two figurative aspects appear: (1) continued use of 'bearing the iniquity' for Judah, same burden metaphor; (2) an explicit symbolic equation 'a day for a year,' where each day of lying represents a year of guilt. These are distinct though related figurative mappings.

deliberation: The verse again uses the idiom 'set your face toward' the siege of Jerusalem and adds 'your arm bared.' Both are conventional Hebrew bodily metaphors/idioms: fixing the face expresses firm resolve/hostility, and the bared arm evokes readiness for decisive action (often military). I treat them as two distinct figurative instances.

deliberation: The verse describes God putting cords on Ezekiel so that he cannot turn until the siege-days are completed. Although the cords themselves participate in the larger sign-act (symbolizing inevitability/constraint), the language here is a straightforward description of binding with cords and not phrased in an idiomatic or metaphorical way.

The mixed-grain bread is highly symbolic within the chapter, indicating scarcity and degraded conditions. However, this verse simply lists ingredients and preparation in literal terms; there is no explicit metaphor, idiom, or other non-literal wording in the Hebrew itself.

The verse gives a precise ration of food by weight. While rationing participates in the symbolic portrayal of famine, the vocabulary and syntax are literal, without idiomatic or metaphorical expressions.
Like v.10, this verse prescribes measured water rations. The terms for measurement and drinking are literal, and no explicit figurative language or idiom appears here.

Ezekiel is told to bake a barley cake on human excrement 'before their eyes.' The act is literal within the vision, but it is designed to symbolize defiled food in exile (explicitly explained in v.13). Thus the baking of bread on human dung functions as a prophetic metaphorical sign-act.

deliberation: This verse interprets the previous sign: Israel will eat their bread 'unclean' among the nations. Ezekiel protests that his 'nephesh' has never been defiled and lists types of forbidden meat he has avoided. The phrase 'נַפְשִׁי לֹא מְטֻמָּאָה' uses 'nephesh' (soul/life) as a metonym/synecdoche for the whole person, a conventional idiom meaning 'I myself have not been defiled.'

deliberation: God grants a modification: cow dung instead of human excrement as fuel. This continues the same symbolic act of vv.12–13 (defiled conditions) but adds no new figurative expression; the wording is a literal substitution of one type of dung for another.

The central figurative expression is 'I am going to break the staff of bread in Jerusalem.' 'Staff of bread' is an idiom/metaphor: bread (food) is pictured as a staff that supports life, and breaking it depicts the collapse of sustenance. The subsequent mention of eating bread by weight and water by measure is literal description of rationing.

deliberation: The verse explains the aim of the famine sign. The notable figurative phrase is 'they shall waste away because of their iniquity' (וְנָמַקּוּ בַּעֲוֺנָם), using a verb that literally means melt/decay for the people’s physical and moral/spiritual deterioration due to sin. This is a metaphor.
